Title: Origin of native copper in the Paraná volcanic province, Brazil, integrating 1 

Cu stable isotopes in a multianalytical approach  2 

 3 

Authors: Sérgio Benjamin Baggio, Léo Afraneo Hartmann, Marina Lazarov, Hans-4 

Joachim Massonne, Joachim Opitz, Thomas Theye, Tillmann Viefhaus  5 

 6 

Abstract 7 

The origin of native copper mineralization in the Paraná volcanic province, the second 8 

largest intraplate province in the continents, still has differing opinions. The 9 

fundamental question is whether the native copper origin was related to magmatic, late-10 

magmatic or hydrothermal events. The copper content average in the host basalts is 11 

around 207 ppm and the native copper occurs as dendrites in the cooling joints, in the 12 

fractures and also infilling cavities of amygdaloidal crust. Mineral phases such as 13 

cuprite, tenorite, chrysocolla, malachite and azurite occur in breccias at the top of the 14 

flows. Gold and silver contents were observed associated with this mineralization. A 15 

combination of chemical analyses, X-ray diffraction, raman spectrometry, electron 16 

microprobe analyses, LA-ICPMS and copper isotope analyses, were used to evaluate 17 

the origin of the copper in the province. Magnetite of the host basalt display Cu contents 18 

close to 1 wt.%. The Cretaceous hydrothermal alteration on magnetite and also 19 

clinopyroxene released the copper from its crystalline structure and generated the 20 

hydrothermal copper mineralization. The isotopic variation (?65Cu) in the native copper 21 

mineralization in the Paraná volcanic province ranges from -0.59 ‰ in the southeast 22 

portion (Rio Grande do Sul state) to 1.89 ‰ in the central portion of province (Paraná 23 

state). This study supports a hydrothermal origin and supergene enrichment for native 24 

copper mineralization in the Paraná volcanic province. 25 



2 

 

 26 

Keywords 27 

Paraná volcanic province, native copper, gold, silver, copper isotopes, hydrothermal 28 

mineralization 29 

 30 

Introduction 31 

Native copper constitutes significant deposits in several basaltic intraplate 32 

provinces (e.g., Emeishan, China; Michigan, North America). The abundant 33 

occurrences registered in the Paraná volcanic province of South America require the 34 

investigation of geological processes involved in the origin of the metal concentrations. 35 

The Paraná province is one of the largest in the continents (e.g., Hartmann et al. 2010) 36 

and may contain significant deposits of copper and possibly gold and silver. 37 

Previous studies suggest conflicting origins for the native copper, including 38 

magmatic (Mello 2000) or late-magmatic (Szubert et al. 1979) deposition and 39 

hydrothermal remobilization (Tazaki et al. 1988; Pinto et al. 2011b; Arena et al. 2014).  40 

In this study X-ray diffraction (XRD) and Raman spectrometry was used to 41 

identify the copper phase minerals. Mineral major elements composition was obtained 42 

with the electron microprobe, while mineral trace element composition was obtained by 43 

laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS). Particular 44 

emphasis is placed on copper isotopes, because this technique is currently essential to 45 

distinguish high-temperature from low-temperature deposits (e.g., Larson et al. 2003; 46 

Seo et al. 2007; Mathur et al. 2009, 2012). The integrated approach supports a 47 

hydrothermal origin for the copper mineralization. 48 

 49 

Geology 50 



3 

 

The Paraná volcanic province in the southern portion of South America (Fig. 1) 51 

is one of the largest igneous provinces of the world (Hartmann et al. 2010) covering 52 

917,000 km2 of area (Frank et al. 2009) including portions in Uruguay, Argentina, 53 

Paraguay and mainly in Brazil. The volume of lava is around 450,000 km3 at the surface 54 

and 112,000 km3 in the subsurface (as sill and dikes). The Etendeka in Namibia, African 55 

continent, was connected to the Paraná volcanic province (Bellieni et al. 1984) before 56 

the opening of the South Atlantic Ocean. The tholeiitic lava flows in the Lower 57 

Cretaceous generated especially basalt (>90 vol.%). However, basaltic andesite, dacite, 58 

rhyodacite and andesite also occur. Rhyolites are present in the southern portion at the 59 

top of the volcanic pile (Melfi et al. 1988) along the Brazilian continental margin and in 60 

Etendeka (Peate 1997). In Brazil, these rocks belong to the Serra Geral Group (Wildner 61 

et al. 2009; Hartmann and Baggio 2014). There is a convergence that the average U-Pb 62 

age is around 130-135 Ma (zircon SHRIMP, Pinto et al. 2011a; baddelyite SIMS, Janasi 63 

et al. 2011). A recent study (zircon SHRIMP, Brückmann et al. 2014) showed that 64 

younger volcanic pulses at 119 Ma occur in the north portion of the province. The 65 

thickness of the volcanic pile is associated with the subsidence of the Paraná Basin. In 66 

Cuiabá Paulista (Fig.1) the volcanic pile reaches the highest known thickness (1723 m) 67 

and becomes thinner to the south, reaching 50 m (Almeida 1986) along the Brazil-68 

Argentina border. According to Peate et al. (1999), the thickness of single flows ranges 69 

from 5 to 80 m and the average thickness of individual flows is about 20 m.  70 

The geochemical subdivision of the Paraná volcanic province based on TiO2 71 

content was proposed by Bellieni et al. (1984) and Mantovani et al. (1985). In the 72 

southern portion, the low-Ti magmas (TiO2<2%) predominates, while the northern part 73 

the high-Ti magmas (TiO2 >2%) are dominant. These two groups was reassessed by 74 

Peate et al. (1992) who proposed a new classification based on major and trace elements 75 



4 

 

and ratio of elements. The low-Ti group was divided into Gramado, Esmeralda and 76 

Ribeira magma types and the high-Ti group into Urubici, Pitanga and Paranapanema 77 

magma types. The study by Nakamura et al. (2003) added an intermediate-Ti type to 78 

this classification, mostly the Paranapanema and Ribeira magma types. The Gramado 79 

and Esmeralda remained in the low-Ti type, the Pitanga and Urubici in the high-Ti type.  80 

The Paranapanema and Ribeira types display low contents of U and Th showing 81 

restricted crustal contamination and larger amount of partial mantle melting when 82 

compared to Pitanga magma type (Nakamura et al. 2003). In the Gramado and 83 

Esmeralda magma-types, the degree of partial melting and crustal contamination are 84 

higher because these magmas were generated in shallower portions with higher Th, U 85 

and Sr isotopic ratios, mainly in the Gramado magma type. The Esmeralda was 86 

considered the most primitive (Nakamura et al. 2003) because of low contents of light 87 

rare elements and relatively high Nd isotopic ratio.  88 

The intermediate-Ti magma-type commonly displays higher contents of copper 89 

when compared with high-Ti and Low-Ti. Arena et al. (2014) indicated that the copper 90 

average in the Paraná volcanic province is around 177 ppm. In the intermediate-Ti host 91 

basalts, the copper content is commonly higher than this average. The largest number of 92 

copper occurrences in the volcanic province is in the Paranapanema magma-type. In 93 

addition some occurrences with native copper, cuprite, tenorite, chrysocolla, malachite 94 

and azurite have been described in hydrothermal breccias at the top of the volcanic 95 

flows and also in the Pitanga magma type as well as Gramado magma-type. 96 

A pioneering study of native copper in the Paraná province by Szubert et al. 97 

(1979) evaluated the genesis of the ore. The study proposed some of the copper 98 

occurrences as late-magmatic (dendritic shape in cooling joints), and others as 99 

supergene (infilling the amygdales of amygdaloidal crust). Tazaki et al. (1988) 100 



5 

 

alternatively suggested that the Cu origin was associated with hydrotermal alteration at 101 

low temperature and can be derived from small amounts of copper in the titano-102 

magnetites. The presence of copper in the Vista Alegre - Frederico Westphalen region 103 

encouraged Costa (1982) to use geophysical prospecting techniques for the 104 

characterization of the occurrences. The study obtained negative results for the 105 

correlation of high induced polarization (IP) with magnetite content of the rocks. 106 

However, high IP results requested further research in at least three flows of the region. 107 

Other studies were performed in the Paraná volcanic province with the focus on the 108 

native copper mineralization (e.g., Mello 2000). Considering the H1, H2 and H3 109 

(Hartmann et al. 2010, 2012a, 2012b) hydrothermal events that acted on the volcanic 110 

rocks Pinto et al. (2011b) proposed a hydrothermal origin of copper with supergene 111 

enrichment in the Vista Alegre region and suggested that the hydrothermal alteration of 112 

opaque minerals and pyroxenes may have released copper to form the mineralization. 113 

 114 

Sampling and Methods 115 

For each occurrence of native copper, one sample from the host basalt and one 116 

from the ore were collected over the geographic distribution of the Paraná volcanic 117 

province (Table 1, Fig. 1). In Rio Grande do Sul state, native copper in dendritic shapes 118 

is present on the surface of cooling joints in quarry 86 in Dom Pedro de Alcântara, in 119 

the Brasília-Guaíba quarry, in Bom Princípio and in the David Basso quarry in 120 

Taquaruçu do Sul (Fig. 2A). In Santo Augusto region, massive balls of native copper 121 

(Fig. 2B) occur in hydrothermal breccias associated with cuprite, tenorite, chrysocolla, 122 

malachite and azurite, quite similar as the copper mineralization in Vista Alegre district 123 

(Pinto et al. 2011b). 124 



6 

 

In Santa Catarina state, the host basalt and the dendritic crystals of native copper 125 

were collected in the locality of São Ludgero on a fracture surface (drill core at 92 m 126 

depth). In the Rebelatto quarry (Fig. 2C) in Palma Sola town, a large amount of native 127 

copper occur in blades and dendrites along the cooling joints of basalt (Fig. 2D). The 128 

native copper occurrence in the nearby locality of Dionísio Cerqueira was also sampled. 129 

In the state of Paraná, several occurrences of native copper are known. In the town of 130 

Francisco Beltrão, dendritic native copper occurs in the cooling joints in Petrocon and 131 

Dalba quarries. In the Quati quarry (Fig. 2E), massive native copper in association with 132 

zeolites and calcite fills the central part of cavities (Fig. 2F) and also occurs as dendrites 133 

in the basal portion of cavities filled later by quartz crystals (Fig. 2G). However, the 134 

main mineralization in Paraná state occurs in the town of Realeza, in the locality of 135 

Linha Capanema (Fig. 2H). Native copper is there associated with hydrothermal 136 

breccias which additionally contain cuprite, chrysocolla and malachite (Fig. 2I). The 137 

mass of chrysocolla and malachite shows a vibrant blue color and appears cementing 138 

the breccias. In the northern portion of the Paraná volcanic province, in the Mato Grosso 139 

do Sul state, the occurrence of copper was observed on a fracture surface of a drill core 140 

at 10 m depth in the town of Amambai, locality of Jaguaretê, and also as very fine 141 

dentrites in the Santo Onofre quarry, locality of Terenos (Fig. 2J) near the city of 142 

Campo Grande. 143 

The host basalt samples were prepared for chemical and X-ray diffraction 144 

analyses. Standard polished thin sections were used for a petrographic study and for 145 

petrographic analyses. Thin section with 40-50 µm thickness were prepared for LA-146 

ICP-MS analyses. Selected crystals of native copper and copper minerals were 147 

embedded in epoxy mounts with 2.5 cm diameter for Raman spectroscopy, electron 148 

microprobe microanalyses, BSE imaging and Cu stable isotope analyses. The analytical 149 



7 

 

work has been performed at Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil 150 

(petrography and XRD), Institut für Mineralogie und Kristallchemie of Universität 151 

Stuttgart, Germany (XRD, Raman spectrometry, Laser Ablation mass spectrometry and 152 

Electron Microprobe), Institut für Mineralogie of the Universität Hannover, Germany 153 

(Cu stable isotope compositions), and ACME Analytical Laboratories, Vancouver, 154 

Canada (major and trace elements of bulk samples). 155 

For the analyses of major elements of bulk rock samples (n=13), the analytical 156 

method comprises melting of 0.1 g sample in lithium metaborate/ tetraborate and 157 

subsequent digestion in nitric acid. Loss on ignition (LOI) is obtained from the weight 158 

difference after heating at 1000 °C. Trace elements and rare earths were analyzed by 159 

ICP-MS following the same procedure of the major elements with the addition of 0.5 g 160 

sample digested in aqua regia. The data were integrated in Excel sheets and interpreted 161 

with support of Geochemical Data Toolkit freeware (GCDKit; http://www.gcdkit.org).  162 

The petrography of the host basalts was studied using a Zeiss Axioplan optical 163 

microscope and the digital ProgRes Jenoptik C10 camera. Some copper minerals were 164 

first identified using an X-ray diffractometer Bruker AXS D8 Advance. To complement 165 

the copper minerals identification, an Olympus BX51 microscope coupled with a 166 

Raman spectrometer (Horiba Xplora) was used. The wavelength was 532 nm or 638 nm 167 

with a power of 0.25 to 25 mW. The exposure time for each scan was 10 s. The number 168 

of scans was between 5 and 100 depending on the laser power and the composition of 169 

the sample, acquired in the spectral range of 70 and 4000 cm-1. The electron microprobe 170 

(EMP Cameca SX100) was used for chemical microanalyses with spot diameter of 1 171 

?m with 15 kV and 5 to 15 nA and also for generation of back-scattered electron images 172 

of native copper crystals. 173 



8 

 

The determination of element concentrations in minerals of the host basalts was 174 

carried out by laser ablation combined with mass spectrometric detection with an 175 

AGILENT 7700 ICPMS and a CETAC LSX-213 laser system. The diameter of the 176 

ablated spots was 50 µm. The laser energy was set to 5% of the maximum (= 4 mJ), 177 

with a frequency of the laser shots of 20 Hz. A mixed helium/argon gas flow with 300 178 

ml/min and 800 ml/min, respectively, served as carrier of the ablated material. A shutter 179 

delay of 10 s was selected to measure the gas blank ion intensities. The standards used 180 

were DLH7 and DLH20 from P & H (Developments Ltd.) and a NIST612 glass. The 181 

following isotopes were monitored: 24Mg, 25Mg, 27Al, 29Si, 39K, 55Mn, 56Fe, 57Fe, 60Ni, 182 

63Cu, 65Cu, 66Zn, 68Zn, 89Y, 90Zr, 91Zr, 93Nb, 95Mo, 107Ag, 109Ag and 197Au. All elemental 183 

concentrations, were calculated relative to an internal standard element (Si) assuming a 184 

natural isotopic distribution. The absolute concentration of the internal standard element 185 

was previously measured by electron microprobe. If more than one isotope of the 186 

studied element was measured, the resulting elemental concentration values were 187 

averaged. The software used for calibration and data evaluation was developed by Dr. 188 

Joachim Opitz of the Institut für Mineralogie und Kristallchemie of the Universität 189 

Stuttgart. 190 

The copper isotope analyses were performed on the Multicollector ICP-MS 191 

(Finnigan Neptune) connected to the deep (194 nm) UV femtosecond laser ablation 192 

system (Spectra Physics Solstice, USA) at Leibniz Universität Hannover, Germany. 193 

Samples and standard were analyzed in line mode applying 35µm spot size. Laser 194 

energy of 16 A and laser pulse frequency of 2-4.5 Hz was used. Instrumental mass bias 195 

discrimination was corrected using the 62Ni/60Ni ratio of the Ni NIST SRM-986 196 

(National Institute of Standards and Technology, USA) standard solution aspirated in to 197 

the plasma and monitored simultaneously with the laser ablation signal of Cu isotopes. 198 



9 

 

Detail instrumental and measurement settings were described by Oeser et al. (2014) and 199 

Lazarov and Horn (2015, submitted). 200 

The solid Cu NIST SRM976 metal standard was used for the standard-sample-201 

standard bracketing for all samples. Usually three sample measurements were run in 202 

between two standards. Obtained results were reported as ?65Cu in per mill (‰) as 203 

follows: ?65Cu = [((65Cu/ 63Cu)sample /(
65Cu/ 63Cu)NIST SRM976)-1]*1000. Internal error for 204 

standard and samples were better than 0.05‰ (2 SD) and overall precision of the 205 

standard measurements was, as reported by Lazarov and Horn 2015 (submitted) for the 206 

other Cu metal, better than 0.08‰ (2 SD). 207 

 208 

Results 209 

Petrographic description, X-Ray diffraction and Raman spectrometry 210 

The basalt host rock samples of the Paraná volcanic province are holocrystalline 211 

and microporphyritic with plagioclase, clinopyroxene and opaque minerals present as 212 

phenocryst phases (0.6 to 1.5 mm). The intergranular texture (Fig. 3A) is usually 213 

formed by small crystals of plagioclase, clinopyroxene and opaque minerals. In some 214 

cases the texture is glomeroporphyritic with phenocrysts of plagioclase and opaque 215 

minerals. The average mineralogical composition of the host rocks of native copper in 216 

the Paraná volcanic province has 45% plagioclase, 30% clinopyroxene, 12% opaque 217 

minerals, 8% microcrystalline matrix, 5% of secondary clay minerals and traces of 218 

apatite. 219 

The crystals of plagioclase are subhedral to euhedral platelets (Fig. 3B) with 220 

random distribution and sharply defined rims. Sometimes, they display compositional 221 

zoning. No alteration of plagioclase has been detected. Magnetite and Ilmenite are 222 

euhedral to anhedral and frequently form poikilitic aggregates. Ilmenite usually occurs 223 



10 

 

as exsolution in magnetite hosts. Sometimes the opaque minerals show hydrothermal 224 

alteration with corroded rims (Fig. 3C). In particular, the formation of a reddish halo 225 

containing hematite can be observed (Fig. 3D). The clinopyroxene (Fig. 3E) is 226 

commonly subhedral to anhedral and usually fractured. The rims are well-defined and 227 

straight mainly near the plagioclase without any signs of corrosion. Only a few crystals 228 

show alteration. 229 

The microcrystalline matrix (Fig. 3F) occurring in the interstitial space between 230 

phenocrysts contains tiny crystals of clinopyroxene (0.05 – 0.1 mm), K-feldspar (?0.1 231 

mm) and quartz (?0.1 mm). Acicular apatite is present as accessory mineral. 232 

The clay minerals present in the host basalts comprise smectite (and celadonite 233 

in some cases) and they are the result of alteration of primary minerals. The occurrence 234 

of native copper in the cavities or in the cooling joints of the host basalt is always 235 

associated with the presence of alteration minerals (clay minerals, zeolites and calcite). 236 

Further copper minerals were identified by XRD and Raman spectroscopy. Three 237 

samples from the Santo Augusto region (JS3a, JS3b and JS3c) in Rio Grande do Sul 238 

state were selected and prepared. The XRD analyses (Fig. 4) of unoriented powder 239 

samples allows the identification of the minerals such as cuprite and malachite. The 240 

XRD of powdered samples also show amorphous (non-crystalline) regions and were 241 

targeted for analyses by Raman spectroscopy. 242 

For the analyses by Raman spectroscopy, in addition to the XRD samples, five 243 

more epoxy mounts (JS2, JS3, JS4, R2P and VA1) with native copper from Santo 244 

Augusto, Cascavel and Vista Alegre region were analyzed. Six copper minerals are 245 

identified: native copper, cuprite, tenorite, chrysocolla and malachite. Azurite peaks 246 

were identified in association with chrysocolla peaks. The native copper (Fig. 5A, B) 247 

shows no Raman signal but has a significant peak at frequencies between 2000 and 248 



11 

 

3100 cm-1. Cuprite (Fig. 5C, D) occurs always associated directly to the native copper, 249 

representing the most frequent copper mineral association in the Paraná province and 250 

displays unambiguous Raman spectra. Tenorite (Fig. 5E, F) is not as common as cuprite 251 

but is always associated with it. Chrysocolla (Fig. 5G, H) and malachite (Fig. 5I, J) can 252 

easily be detected from the Raman spectra, in the same way as quartz, magnetite, 253 

hematite and zeolite (heulandite). Silver was also detected in the Raman spectra 254 

(frequencies at 611.5, 523.9, 207.7, 140.1, 89.1 and 52.5 cm-1) and occurs in association 255 

with the native copper and copper phases in several places in the province (Fig. 6). 256 

 257 

Chemical analyses 258 

The volcanic rocks of the study area were chemically analyzed and the data are 259 

presented in Table 2. Analysis VA1 corresponds to sample VVA-12 of Pinto and 260 

Hartmann (2011), analysis FM79 to sample LC3B of Arena et al. (2014), and sample 261 

W247 to sample VIF11 of Pinto and Hartmann (2011). 262 

According to the classification of Le Bas et al. (1986), the rocks are basalt and 263 

basaltic andesite (Fig. 7A) with SiO2 contents between 49.54-50.86 wt.% for the basalts 264 

and 53 wt.% for the basaltic andesites. The content of Na2O + K2O is between 2.81-4.5 265 

wt.% for the basalts and 4.76 wt.% for basaltic andesite. The intermediate-Ti 266 

Paranapanema magma-type is predominant among the host basalts of native copper 267 

mineralization, but the copper also occurs in the low-Ti Gramado magma-type and 268 

high-Ti Pitanga magma-type (Fig. 7B). The chemical analyses show the lowest contents 269 

of copper in the southwest portion of province between 83 ppm (Dom Pedro de 270 

Alcântara, Rio Grande do Sul) and 97.7 ppm (Bom Princípio, Rio Grande do Sul), while 271 

the highest contents are between 292.2 ppm (Dionísio Cerqueira, Santa Catarina) and 272 

324.4 ppm (Frederico Westphalen, Rio Grande do Sul). The average content of the 273 



12 

 

analyzed samples (n=16) is 207 ppm, slightly above the Cu average content established 274 

by Arena et al. (2014) for the Paraná volcanic province. In the sample DC6, the contents 275 

of copper reach 1114.7 ppm, and this value was considered as a nugget effect, because 276 

the sample includes fine cooling joints filled by native copper.  277 

In the hydrothermal environments such as the Paraná volcanic province, LOI is 278 

one of the important geochemical characteristics because it is a proxy of the 279 

hydrothermal alteration (Hartmann et al. 2010; Duarte et al. 2009, 2011; Rosenstengel 280 

and Hartmann 2012) and the LOI versus copper contents showed great regional 281 

variation. Copper shows no correlation with oxides such as SiO2, Al2O, MgO, CaO, 282 

Na2O, K2O, TiO2, P2O5 or Cr2O3, whereas MnO and Fe2O3 display positive correlation 283 

with copper (Fig. 7C). The correlation of copper with the trace elements is not 284 

significant except with rare earth elements that show a positive correlation trend, in 285 

particular with the heavy rare earth elements (Fig. 7D). This correlation indicates that 286 

the host basalts flows have mantle origin, without significant crustal contamination. 287 

 288 

Electron probe microanalyses and LA-ICP-MS data 289 

The electron microprobe analyses (n= 305) were performed in native copper 290 

crystals (Fig. 8) mainly with the purpose to evaluate the chemistry of copper. 291 

Additionally they were very useful for the choice of fields for analyses of minerals by 292 

LA-ICP-MS in the host basalts and also for the selection and imaging of native copper 293 

crystals for the isotopic analyses. 294 

Representative microanalyses of native copper crystals (Table 3) from the 295 

Paraná volcanic province show that the average copper content in the native copper 296 

crystals is 99.7 wt. %. The elements Sn, Ca, Co, Ni and U show lower values with 297 

virtually no Al. The sulfur displays an average content of 0.026 wt. % (n= 270, sd= 298 



13 

 

0.012) and the Si was detected only in a few crystals with maximum of 0.404 wt. %. 299 

The evaluation of the silver content shows large oscillations both in microanalyses of 300 

the same sample and along the Paraná volcanic province. The average of silver contents 301 

is 0.027 wt.%. In these native copper crystals with silver inclusions, the microanalyses 302 

show the same wide variation in the contents of silver. On the other hand it was 303 

observed that some analyzes are far above the average and have values up to 0.283 wt. 304 

%. Similar to the behavior of silver, gold varies significantly between the smallest and 305 

largest values. Furthermore, gold crystals were not observed in association with native 306 

copper in the province. 307 

The LA-ICP-MS analyses were performed mainly in order to evaluate the 308 

content of copper within the major minerals of the host basalts. The contents of Ag and 309 

Au were also evaluated to define possible relationship with the copper content. The 310 

analyzed minerals are magnetite (Fig. 9A), ilmenite (Fig. 9B), clinopyroxene (Fig. 9C), 311 

plagioclase and smectite (Fig. 9D). The analyzed minerals were identified by their 312 

sample number followed by the number given to each mineral analysis (e.g. BP1-313 

MG7A). 314 

The analyses obtained in magnetite (Table 4) show that the average content of 315 

copper (n= 30 spots) is around 1085 ppm with a highly variable distribution from 316 

negligible values in sample BP1 (12 ppm) to very high contents in sample PQ16 (>9000 317 

ppm). Four LA spots measurements in ilmenite from sample PQ16 (Table 4) shows that 318 

the distribution of copper is similar to that observed in magnetite. However, the highest 319 

copper content in ilmenite is 3827 ppm, nearly three times smaller than the higher 320 

copper content observed in the magnetite of the same sample. In the clinopyroxene 321 

(Table 5), the copper content is smaller than that observed in the magnetite and ilmenite 322 

with great variation. The average is 97 ppm (n= 28 spots) and ranges from very low 323 



14 

 

values of 0.72 ppm to maximum values of 431 ppm. Regarding the copper content of 324 

plagioclase, the observed values have the same characteristic of variation, although the 325 

range of copper content is smaller and comprises from 0.02 ppm to a maximum of 91.90 326 

ppm. Despite the wide variation in the copper contents of the minerals, magnetite 327 

contains the largest contents of copper followed by ilmenite and clinopyroxene. The 328 

highest contents of copper obtained in magnetite are up to 3 times higher than those 329 

observed in ilmenite and up to 22 times those of clinopyroxene. The minerals that fill 330 

the interstices (matrix) of the host basalts are usually clinopyroxene, K-feldspar, apatite 331 

and in a few cases quartz with sizes from 0.05 to 0.1 mm. The LA spot in this mixed 332 

and interstitial material (sample FS86) showed 16.02 ppm copper. 333 

Overall in the fields for LA analyses was also observed that the crystals of 334 

magnetite, ilmenite and clinopyroxene display different levels of hydrothermal 335 

alteration. Some crystals of magnetite and clinopyroxene exhibit lightly corroded rims 336 

and others crystals of magnetite-ilmenite display formation of hematite and in the 337 

extreme cases profound alteration and formation of smectites (Fig. 10 A, B and C). The 338 

presence of smectites was observed in all samples of host rock in the Paraná volcanic 339 

province. 340 

The LA-ICP-MS analyzes in smectites (Table 6) showed that the copper content 341 

is extremely varied similar to magnetite, ilmenite and clinopyroxene. However, the 342 

higher contents of copper are observed in the smectites of host basalt with higher 343 

mineral alteration. These copper contents outweigh all other values observed in 344 

magnetite, ilmenite and clinopyroxene. From this alteration, the copper metal is released 345 

from magnetite, ilmenite and clinopyroxene and is concentrated initially in the smectites 346 

(Fig. 10 D, E and F) 347 



15 

 

The LA-ICP-MS analyses also indicate the contents of silver and gold in the 348 

minerals. The contents of silver range from 0.04 to 1.78 ppm in magnetite, and reach 349 

2.75 ppm in a crystal of ilmenite. In clinopyroxene, these values vary from 0.01 to 1.03 350 

ppm and in the smectite these contents range from 0.01 to 1.84 ppm. The contents of 351 

gold range from 0.01 to 0.12 ppm in magnetite, 0.01 to 0.07 ppm in ilmenite, 0.01 to 352 

0.12 ppm in clinopyroxene and 0.01 to 0.14 ppm in smectites. 353 

 354 

Cu isotope composition of Cu minerals 355 

Recent advances in mass spectrometry techniques have enabled an improvement 356 

in the accuracy of the ratios of the isotopes of copper and their use in studies of the 357 

origin of copper. Among the methods for copper isotopic analysis, the in situ UV-358 

femtosecond laser ablation has been considered one of the most accurate (Lazarov and 359 

Horn 2015, submitted). Like for studies of iron isotopes (Horn et al. 2006; Horn and 360 

Von Blanckenburg, 2007), the in situ measurements of Cu isotopes (Lazarov and Horn 361 

2015, submitted) by UV- femtosecond laser MC-ICP-MS showed no isotopic 362 

fractionation even when the analyses were conducted without matrix match or when 363 

using different protocols (spots, lines and raster) between samples and calibration 364 

standards. 365 

This is the first study of copper isotopes in the Paraná volcanic province and 366 

allows new insights on the copper origin. Eleven samples with Cu minerals (native Cu 367 

and Cu bearing samples) were selected in the states of Rio Grande do Sul (samples 368 

FS86, BP1, JS3, JS4, PD1 and W247), Santa Catarina (DC6 and NZ1) and Paraná (P1C, 369 

CP14 and R2P). Some of these samples had more than one analysed native copper 370 

crystal, that were identified by the sample number followed by “a, b and c” (e.g., 371 

FS86a). 372 



16 

 

Along 1400 km of studied exposures in the host basalts, the copper isotopic 373 

ratios (Table 7) display three distributions. The most frequent has values between -0.2 374 

‰ and 0.71 ‰ (n = 41). In this variation stands out the isotopic ratios between 0.4 ‰ 375 

and 0.7 ‰ as values more repeating in the analyses. The second shows values between 376 

1.07 ‰ and 1.89 ‰ (n = 9). This variation has a discontinuous interval where the 377 

greatest occurrences are between 1 ‰ and 1.2 ‰ (n = 6). The other analyses are in the 378 

interval between 1.5 ‰ and 1.6 ‰ and a single analysis in 1.89‰. The third introduces 379 

samples with values from -0.59 ‰ to -0.91 ‰. These negative values present an 380 

analysis with isotope ratio of -0.59 ‰ and four analyzes between -0.83 ‰ and -0.91 ‰. 381 

The Dom Pedro de Alcântara region in the southeastern part of the volcanic 382 

province . Sample FS86 display different native copper crystals in the same sample and 383 

the isotopic ratios average is -0.81‰ for FS86a and 0.06‰ for the crystal FS86b. In the 384 

Bom Princípio region, the isotopic values ?65Cu in the sample BP1 has isotopic ratios 385 

average of 0.43‰. In the Santo Augusto region, two samples were evaluated, JS3 (a - 386 

native copper and b - chrysocolla) and JS4 (a, c - native copper and b - cuprite). Sample 387 

JS3a displays native copper isotopic average ratios of 0.14‰ and the average values 388 

ratios for JS3b (chrysocolla) is -0.31 ‰. In sample JS4a, the isotopic average ratios for 389 

native copper showed 0.64 ‰ while in cuprite the average isotopic values was 0.18 ‰ 390 

in the core and for the crystal rim display a isotope variation from 0.10 – 0.73 ‰. The 391 

sample JS3c shows isotope ratios of 1.07‰. In the region between Taquaruçu do Sul 392 

and Frederico Westphalen was observed a large isotopic variation in the native copper 393 

crystals of the same sample, and regionally. The native copper in sample PD1a showed 394 

isotopic average ratios of 0.70 ‰ and in sample PD1b the isotopic ratios average is 1.16 395 

‰ whereas the sample W247 shows isotopic variations between the crystal core (0.37 396 

‰) and rim (-0.14 ‰). 397 



17 

 

The region of Dionisio Cerqueira (sample DC6) and Palma Sola (sample NZ1) 398 

in Santa Catarina state, show values of ?65Cu from 0.49 ‰ (NZ1) to 1.10 ‰ (DC6). 399 

Crossing to the Paraná state, the Sample P1C in Francisco Beltrão region shows ?65Cu 400 

values of 0.36 ‰ in the crystal rim and 0.39 ‰ in the core. In the Cascavel region near 401 

to the depocenter (greater thickness of the volcanic pile) of the Paraná volcanic 402 

province, the sample CP14 shows two sizes of native copper crystals. The mm-sized 403 

native copper (CP14a) has isotopic average ratios of 0.57 ‰, while in the cm-sized 404 

native copper (CP14b) the isotope average ratios is 1.63 ‰ indicating at least two 405 

different native copper mineralization in the same sample. Sample R2P which presents 406 

native copper mineralization with quartz, the isotopic average ratios is 0.57 ‰. The 407 

lowest isotopic value for native copper (-0.91‰) is observed in the Rio Grande do Sul 408 

state and the highest value (1.89 ‰) in the Paraná State. These isotopic variations (Fig. 409 

11) is here interpreted as associated with the processes that originated the copper 410 

deposits and can be compared to the isotopic data of copper deposits in the USA (Table 411 

8) and show a quite similar variation as the hydrothermal deposits from Keweenaw 412 

volcanic province, Michigan, USA (Fig. 11) and supergene deposits (Fig. 11). 413 

 414 

Discussions and interpretations 415 

The origin of copper deposits has sparkled theories and genetic models that seek 416 

to explain the different processes for a wide variety of native copper deposits in host 417 

rocks such as basic and ultrabasic igneous rocks, sedimentary rocks and also in sulphide 418 

deposits. In the Paraná volcanic province, controversy was generated centered in at least 419 

three theories about the origin of native copper based on magmatic, late-magmatic, and 420 

hydrothermal models. The magmatic origin suggested by Mello (2000) was based in the 421 

native copper mineralization at the surface of cooling joints (Água Perdida region, 422 



18 

 

Paraná). According to the author the temperature of cooling joint formation was 750 ºC 423 

and at this temperature a residual and immiscible fluid, rich in copper, migrated to this 424 

space generating a native copper mineralization with timing correlated to the lava 425 

solidification processes. The late-magmatic origin indicated by Szubert et al. (1979) 426 

suggests that the native copper mineralization (Itapiranga region, Santa Catarina) in the 427 

microfractures and in the core of basaltic flows originated from late-magmatic processes 428 

(hydrothermal processes included but not detailed). The hydrothermal origin indicated 429 

by Pinto et al. (2011b) and Arena et al. (2014) is supported in the present study. 430 

Regarding the magmatic origin, it is worth noting that the magmatic processes 431 

are conditioned to high-temperatures so the native copper crystallization occurs in 432 

equilibrium with the magma. In deposits at this temperature, copper isotopes show 433 

?
65Cu ratios ~ 0‰ and no significant fractionation (Markl et al. 2006). The isotopic 434 

composition of native copper crystals in ultramafic rocks (Albarede 2004; Ikehata and 435 

Hirata 2012) shows ?
65Cu values between -0.03 ‰ and 0.14 ‰ supporting the absence 436 

of significant copper fractionation during magmatic, high-temperature processes, thus 437 

higher values than 0.3 ‰ cannot be expected in these temperatures. In this case, the 438 

copper mineralization in the Paraná volcanic province should have ?65Cu values close to 439 

0 ‰ but this is not the case, they are more fractionated and must have been modified 440 

during the formation of mineralization. 441 

The study carried out by Cabral and Beaudoin (2007) in the Quebec 442 

Appalachians (Canada) suggest the occurrence of native copper crystals of magmatic 443 

origin. According to that study, the native copper occurs as inclusions (~ 50 µm in 444 

length) in feldspars and the authors present an S versus As diagram from the high-445 

temperature native copper from Quebec, Canada, and the low-temperature native copper 446 

deposits from the Keweenaw volcanic province, Michigan. The comparison highlights 447 



19 

 

the electron probe analyses that show the high concentrations of sulfur and arsenic in 448 

the high-temperature native copper from Québec and the low concentrations of sulfur 449 

and arsenic in the low-temperature native copper from Michigan. In the Paraná 450 

province, the host volcanic flows of copper mineralization have essentially mantle 451 

origin according copper contents versus rare earth elements correlations. In the same 452 

way, the EPMA analyses in the copper native crystals shows very low sulfur content 453 

(0.03 wt. %) and is accompanied by contents of arsenic below the electron microprobe 454 

detection limit, similarly to the low-temperature copper mineralization of Michigan. A 455 

careful search for native copper inclusions was made by backscattered electrons images 456 

in the primary minerals of the host basalt. However no evidence of magmatic copper 457 

crystals associated with the primary minerals was observed. This observation requires 458 

further detail. The native copper mineralization on the surface of the cooling joint in the 459 

basalts of the Paraná volcanic province acts as a time marker. Surface cracking (e.g. 460 

Kilauea volcano) according to Peck and Minakami (1968) starts at 900 ºC, but the 461 

cooling joint is formation completed when the bulk of the flow (e.g. Big Lost River 462 

flow, USA) reaches around 750ºC (Lore et al. 2000). The structure is only completed 463 

when all magmatic processes come to an end and the volcanic rock is consolidated. The 464 

copper mineralization in the Paraná volcanic province was generated after the formation 465 

of the cooling joints. In addition, the native copper occurs associated with a low 466 

temperature mineral assemblage. Other evidence can be seen in the host basalts where 467 

the native copper is associated with smectite and also in cavities where the rounded 468 

massive copper occurs in the core, associated with zeolites and/or calcite in the rim. 469 

Accordingly, the native copper origin in the Paraná volcanic province is not compatible 470 

with magmatic processes. The hydrothermal hypothesis for the copper origin in the 471 



20 

 

Parana volcanic province can explain the mineralization based on the evidence 472 

presented in this study. 473 

The Cretaceous native copper mineralization in the study area can be compared 474 

with the Proterozoic mineralization of native copper from Keweenaw Province, USA, 475 

and also with the Upper Permian mineralization of native copper from Emeishan 476 

volcanic province in China. In the Keweenaw Province, the native copper deposits are 477 

hosted at the top of rift subaerial basaltic lava (Bornhorst and Barron 2011). Also, fluid 478 

inclusion studies (Livnat, 1983) indicated that the hydrothermal fluids at 150-200 ºC 479 

crossed the underlying sedimentary sequence (conglomerates) and the volcanic pile to 480 

deposit the native copper. In the Emeishan province, the hosting volcanic rocks (basalts, 481 

breccias and tuffs) with bitumen have Cu average contents of 200 ppm (Li et al. 2005) 482 

and are interbedded with carbonaceous sedimentary rocks. The native copper 483 

mineralization is hosted in the breccias, in the amygdaloidal crust and also in the 484 

sedimentary sequence at the top of the basalt flows. In places, the copper replaces and 485 

fills bitumenous fissures in the basaltic rock. The minerals are characterized by a low-486 

temperature assemblage of laumontite, epidote and quartz and the hydrothermal 487 

mineralization is epigenetic (Li et al. 2005). In the Paraná volcanic province, the H1, H2 488 

and H3 hydrothermal events were identified, defined and described by Hartmann et al. 489 

(2008, 2012a, 2012b). These events were triggered by boiling water and its vapour from 490 

the Guarani aquifer that migrated upwards into the volcanic pile and promoted alteration 491 

in the host basalts, zeolites deposition and native copper mineralization in cooling 492 

joints, fractures and cavities. 493 

The description of hydrothermal processes in the Paraná volcanic province 494 

requires an evaluation of the copper source that generated the mineralization. In the 495 

Michigan district, one of the discussions that have permeated this issue for over a 496 



21 

 

hundred years is the presence of copper in the crystal structure of iron minerals 497 

(magnetite) in the host basalts, its chemical changes and the concentration of copper 498 

(e.g., Butler and Burbank 1929). The study performed by Cornwall (1956) in the 499 

Michigan native copper describes the presence of copper in magnetite (200 – 800 ppm), 500 

ilmenite (90 – 300 ppm), clinopyroxene (51 – 320 ppm) and plagioclase (20 – 73 ppm). 501 

In the Paraná volcanic province some studies (e.g. Tazaki et al. 1988; Arioli 2008; Pinto 502 

et al. 2011b) have also suggested the presence of copper in magnetite. 503 

The LA-ICPMS analyses in this study show that the minerals of the host basalt 504 

contain copper, mainly magnetite. This finding contributes to a better understanding of 505 

the behavior of copper during the hydrothermal events. The chemical reactions triggered 506 

by the boiling water from the Guarani aquifer in the host basalts promoted the alteration 507 

of magnetite-hematite to clay minerals and released the copper from its crystal lattice. 508 

The hydrothermal fluids leached the copper and promote the first concentration in the 509 

clay minerals (smectites). As the hydrothermal activity was developing, copper was 510 

being deposited along the cooling joints that served as a pressure relief for hydrothermal 511 

fluids. Similarly, the copper mineralization was generated in the cavities in the 512 

amygdaloidal crust. Studies in monophase fluid inclusions in amethyst deposits (Gilg et 513 

al. 2003; Duarte et al. 2009; Morteani et al. 2010; Juchem 2014) showed that the 514 

evolved boiling fluids had low salinity and temperatures up to 150 ºC, although Gilg et 515 

al. (2014) determined the additional presence of high-salinity fluids. The presence of 516 

heulandite identified by Raman spectroscopy and calcite means that the copper 517 

mineralogical association has been formed at temperatures lower than 200 °C (Carr et 518 

al. 1999). These temperatures are consistent with those indicated by Pinto et al (2011b) 519 

to the copper mineralization in the Vista Alegre mining district (100 – 150 ºC) Paraná 520 



22 

 

volcanic province and also for the hydrothermal alteration assembly (smectites, zeolites, 521 

quartz and calcite). 522 

Au and Ag contents are present both in host basalts and in the native copper 523 

crystals, but also show no clear correlation between them in the copper mineralization 524 

of Paraná volcanic province. The experimental hydrothermal mechanisms for gold and 525 

silver (transport and concentration) in epithermal systems (Cole and Drumond 1986; 526 

Williams-Jones and Heinrich 2005) are based on pressures and temperatures which 527 

coexist with boiling liquid-vapor phases. The model predicts that the vapor transport 528 

capacity of metal is greater than that of hot water. This explosive mechanism was 529 

indicated by Arena et al. (2014) for the leaching, transport and mineralization of copper, 530 

gold and silver in the Realeza region, Paraná volcanic province. At a temperature of 150 531 

°C, the vapor carrying metal can mix with groundwater that is close to the surface and 532 

form metal mineralization as mentioned by Williams-Jones and Heinrich (2005). 533 

Similar mechanism occurred in the copper mineralization along the Paraná volcanic 534 

province. The Cretaceous hydrothermal boiling fluids with copper percolated through 535 

the cooling joints and fractures and formed the native copper mineralization. 536 

The process of forming copper deposits trigger many fractionation mechanisms 537 

that are not fully understood. Several studies (e.g., Zhu et al. 2000; Larson et al. 2003; 538 

Markl et al. 2006) suggest that these mechanisms are influenced by redox reactions, 539 

valence of copper ions, speciation in solution and in some cases organic process. In 540 

hydrothermal deposits the most significant mechanisms are liquid-vapor separation, 541 

multi-step equilibrium processes and physical/chemical parameters (temperature, 542 

oxygen fugacity, pH and salinity of the fluid). These processes leave their marks as 543 

fingerprints in the copper isotope ratios which can be used to define the origin of the 544 

deposits (Maréchal et al. 1999; Dekov et al. 2013; Zhang et al. 2013) and also to 545 



23 

 

distinguish high from low-temperature processes. The Cu isotope fractionation 546 

(sulfides) in hydrothermal systems (Graham et al. 2004) is associated with the process 547 

of Cu leaching and by the ore-bearing fluid. The isotope fractionation is differentiated 548 

for hydrothermal vapor and for fluid phase. Multiple mineralization events could occur 549 

from a fluid with different Cu isotopic composition, oxygen/sulfur fugacity, temperature 550 

and chemical composition. In the copper hydrothermal deposits hosted in basalts 551 

(Larson et al. 2003) the copper isotopic values are more similar to the mantle (~ 0 ‰), 552 

and overlap the values of chalcopyrite in mafic intrusions with isotope variation extends 553 

to higher values. 554 

In the supergene environments the redox processes affect strongly the copper 555 

isotopic compositions (Larson et al. 2003; Maher 2005; Markl et al. 2006; Mathur et al. 556 

2012) and represents varied and repetitive fractionation processes (leaching, oxidation 557 

and reduction) controlled by changes in the water system over time (Maher, 2005). 558 

However, extremely high fractionation (9 ‰) may reflect an open system or kinetic 559 

fractionation (Sherman, 2013). The variation in ?65Cu (Maher, 2005) of supergene 560 

deposits involves three processes, the leaching of copper from existing minerals, the 561 

change in the valence of copper and the precipitation of copper mineral. The degree of 562 

leaching of 65Cu in the copper precursor mineral defines the final isotope ratios. 563 

Supergene copper minerals co-existing in the same sample can be isotopically heavier 564 

than the copper precursor mineral (Asael et al. 2007), but the low-temperature 565 

fractionation (Maréchal and Sheppard, 2002) can precipitate minerals isotopically 566 

lighter than the fluid. The supergene enrichment displays oxidized secondary phases 567 

(e.g., cuprite) with isotopic ratios higher than native copper. The ?65Cu variation in the 568 

supergene native copper deposits range between -3.03 ‰ (Maréchal et al. 1999) to 0.72 569 

‰ (Larson et al. 2003) and up to 1.26 ‰ (Larson et al. 2003) when associated with 570 



24 

 

cuprite. These variations overlap the isotope ratios from Michigan native copper 571 

hydrothermal deposits (Larson et al. 2003; Maher 2005). 572 

In the Paraná volcanic province the hydrothermal system with boiling fluids 573 

(water and its vapour) generated a wide mineralization of native copper. The ?65Cu 574 

ratios variations in the native copper was interpreted as isotopic fractionation reactions 575 

during the H1, H2 and H3 (Hartmann et al., 2008, 2012a, 2012b) low-temperature 576 

hydrothermal events and by the supergene environment that affected the native copper 577 

mineralization. The succession of hydrothermal events, added to redox reactions in the 578 

exposed volcanic flows at the surface ensured the formation of the secondary co-579 

existing copper minerals with native copper as precursor mineral and is supported by 580 

the values of ?65Cu from 0.3 ‰ up to 1.89 ‰. Similarly local variations occur in several 581 

places of the province. In the sample JS4 the isotope ratios of 0.65 ‰ and 1.07 ‰ show 582 

the fractionation of two different events of hydrothermal native copper mineralization. 583 

The cuprite in this sample shows an isotope variation in the core (~ 0.18 ‰) with more 584 

fractionated ?65Cu (up to 0.73 ‰) in the rim. In the same region, in sample JS3, was 585 

observed chrysocolla with lighter isotope ratios (~ 0.31 ‰). In the regions of Dom 586 

Pedro de Alcantara (FS86a, b), Santo Augusto (JS4a, c), Taquaruçu do Sul (PD1a, b) 587 

and Cascavel (CP14a, b) the variation of isotope ratios reflect multiple hydrothermal 588 

mineralization with different times of copper leaching and fractionation along the fluid 589 

flow pathway. Different degrees of leaching and stronger fractionation of the Cu 590 

isotopes (W247, P1C) in the supergene environment were observed in the Frederico 591 

Westphalen (RS), and Francisco Beltrão (PR) regions. Accordingly, in the Paraná 592 

volcanic province the origin of the copper is hydrothermal. Multiple copper 593 

mineralization process occurs with leaching and mineral precipitation along the time 594 

and different fractionation of copper and isotope ratio variation. 595 



25 

 

 596 

Conclusions 597 

Hydrothermal native copper mineralization is widespread in the Paraná volcanic 598 

province as dendrides and needles in the cooling joints, fractures and also filling 599 

cavities in the amygdaloidal crust. Apart from native copper, other mineral phases such 600 

as cuprite, tenorite, chrysocolla, malachite and azurite make up the copper 601 

mineralization. 602 

The origin of copper in the Paraná volcanic province is associated with the 603 

magma that rose from the mantle to the surface and formed the basaltic flows. The 604 

copper was added in the crystal lattice of the basalt forming minerals. As a 605 

consequence, the copper content average in the host basalts is 207 ppm. The Cretaceous 606 

H1, H2 and H3 (Hartmann et al., 2008, 2012a, 2012b) hydrothermal events altered the 607 

volcanic rocks. The minerals most affected by the hydrothermal alteration were 608 

magnetite, ilmenite, clinopyroxenes and the microcrystalline matrix. From this process 609 

smectites were formed. Copper, silver and gold were released from the crystal structure 610 

of igneous minerals. The copper initially was concentrated in the smectites. The 611 

transport of copper was supported by boiling water and vapor at temperature of 100 - 612 

150 °C. The native copper was deposited along the network path crossed by the 613 

hydrothermal fluid in the cooling joints, fractures and within the vesicles of 614 

amygdaloidal crust. The variations of isotope ratios reflect Cu-mineralization pulses that 615 

occurred during the hydrothermal and supergene events. This study thus makes a major 616 

contribution to the understanding of the hydrothermal origin of the native copper 617 

mineralization in the large Paraná volcanic province. Of particular significance is the 618 

multianalytical approach in the study, with emphasis on copper isotopes. 619
